deliberation: Considered the imperatives 'listen' and 'look' as conventional for attention. The dominant image is the 'rock' and 'quarry' as the source from which Israel was hewn, which is a clear metaphor for their ancestral origins (later specified as Abraham/Sarah). Treated that complex as one figurative instance.

instances.hebrew_text: הַבִּ֙יטוּ֙ אֶל־צ֣וּר חֻצַּבְתֶּ֔ם וְאֶל־מַקֶּ֥בֶת בּ֖וֹר נֻקַּרְתֶּֽם
instances.english_text: Look to the rock you were hewn from, To the quarry you were dug from.
ground: being shaped and derived from a solid source
instances.explanation: Israel’s ancestral origin is depicted as stone cut from a rock and quarry, evoking solidity and deliberate shaping; the rock/quarry stands for Abraham/Sarah and the founding promises.

deliberation: Abraham as 'your father' and Sarah as one who 'bore you' are genealogically true from Israel’s perspective; 'one' being made 'many' refers to literal multiplication of descendants. Any conceptual metaphor of corporate ancestry is very conventional. No distinct, marked figurative expression beyond normal kinship language.

Zion and her ruins are treated as a comforted entity, implying personification. The wilderness/desert becoming like Eden/‘the garden of YHWH’ is a clear paired simile. 'Thanksgiving and the sound of music' function metonymically for worshipful life in the city.

instances.english_text: Truly the LORD has comforted Zion, Comforted all her ruins—
ground: ability to experience sorrow and receive comfort
instances.explanation: Zion and its physical ruins are spoken of as if they were a person who can be comforted, personifying the city and its desolate places.

instances.english_text: Made her wilderness like Eden, Her desert like the Garden of the LORD.
instances.explanation: The once-barren land around Zion is explicitly compared to Eden and the garden of the LORD, depicting the restoration as paradisal.

instances.hebrew_text: שָׂשׂוֹן וְשִׂמְחָה יִמָּצֵא בָהּ תּוֹדָה וְקוֹל זִמְרָה
instances.english_text: Gladness and joy shall abide there, Thanksgiving and the sound of music.
target: life and worship in restored Zion
ground: audible expressions indicate inner joy and corporate worship
ritual stands for whole life of praise
instances.explanation: ‘Thanksgiving’ and ‘sound of singing’ stand metonymically for the whole restored worship and joyful communal life in Zion.

deliberation: Looked at ‘give ear’ as conventional. Identified two separate metaphors: Torah “going out” from God as if it were a dispatched entity, and God’s justice functioning as ‘light’ for peoples.

instances.english_text: For teaching shall go forth from Me
ground: originating at God and moving outward to recipients
instances.explanation: Torah is portrayed as something that ‘goes forth’ from God, as if a dispatched agent or flowing stream, emphasizing its dynamic spread.

instances.english_text: My way [justice] for the light of peoples. In a moment I will bring it.
instances.explanation: God’s justice is presented as ‘light’ for peoples, likening its effect to illumination that guides and clarifies.

deliberation: Focused on the phrase ‘my arms’ judging and the coastlands hoping ‘for my arm.’ This is anthropomorphic and metonymic for divine power in action, a standard Isaiah image.

instances.english_text: My arms shall provide for the peoples; ... They shall look to My arm.
ground: strength, reach, capacity to act decisively
instances.explanation: God’s ‘arm(s)’ stand metonymically for His powerful action; people trusting in His ‘arm’ trust His might to judge and save.

deliberation: Noted two explicit similes: heavens vanishing ‘like smoke’ and earth wearing out ‘like a garment.’ They contrast the transient cosmos with God’s enduring salvation.

instances.english_text: Though the heavens should melt away like smoke
instances.explanation: The heavens are compared to smoke that vanishes, a hyperbolic simile stressing their impermanence relative to God’s salvation.

instances.english_text: And the earth wear out like a garment
instances.explanation: The earth is likened to clothing that wears out, emphasizing that even seemingly solid creation is temporary compared with God’s enduring salvation.

deliberation: The key figurative element is ‘my Torah in their heart,’ using ‘heart’ as the seat of inner cognition/will and picturing instruction as something housed within. Treated this as one metaphor; insults/jeers are literal.

instances.english_text: O people who lay My instruction to heart!
instances.explanation: Having Torah ‘in the heart’ metaphorically pictures God’s teaching as placed within the inner self, not merely externally known.

deliberation: Identified two parallel similes: enemies consumed by moth and by worm as garments/wool are. These depict the fragility of human opponents. God’s enduring righteousness is stated straightforwardly.

instances.english_text: For the moth shall eat them up like a garment
instances.explanation: The enemies’ demise is compared to a moth’s slow consumption of clothing, stressing how fragile and temporary they are.

instances.english_text: The worm shall eat them up like wool.
instances.explanation: The hostile people are likened to wool devoured by worms, reinforcing the idea that they will be quietly but completely destroyed.

deliberation: Two main figurative complexes: (1) the ‘arm of YHWH’ addressed and told to awaken and clothe itself with strength—anthropomorphic personification of divine power; (2) the references to ‘Rahab’ and ‘the dragon’ as mythic sea monsters representing a chaos/oppressor power cut down by God.

instances.english_text: Awake, awake, clothe yourself with splendor, O arm of the LORD!
vehicle: an arm that awakens and puts on strength
ground: capacity to act forcefully in battle
ability to be aroused to action
instances.explanation: God’s power is portrayed as His ‘arm,’ which is summoned to awake and put on strength like a warrior, both anthropomorphizing and personifying divine might.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲלֹוא אַתְּ־הִיא הַמַּחְצֶבֶת רַהַב מְחוֹלֶלֶת תַּנִּין
instances.english_text: It was you that hacked Rahab in pieces, That pierced the Dragon.
target: the historical/primeval oppressor opposed by God
forces hostile to YHWH and His people
ground: dangerous, proud, chaotic power defeated by divine might
instances.explanation: ‘Rahab’ and ‘the Dragon’ are mythic sea-monster figures, metaphorically representing an arrogant, chaotic oppressor that God previously shattered.

deliberation: Most of the verse retells the Red Sea event, which in context is treated as historical miracle. The key figurative term is ‘the redeemed’ (גְּאוּלִים), a metaphor drawn from the law of redemption.

instances.english_text: A road the redeemed might walk.
vehicle: those who have been legally redeemed
persons bought back by a kinsman
ground: having been released from prior claim or bondage by an act of purchase/rescue
instances.explanation: The people who passed through the sea are called ‘the redeemed,’ applying the legal image of purchase/redemption to God’s act of deliverance.

deliberation: Saw two main figurative elements: joy portrayed as something resting upon the head like a crown, and sorrow/sighing personified as fleeing away from the redeemed.

instances.english_text: Crowned with joy everlasting [literally: everlasting joy upon their heads].
target: the inner and social state of the returning exiles
ground: conspicuous, exalted joy marking them out
honor and festivity visible to all
instances.explanation: Joy is pictured as resting upon their heads like a crown, suggesting that unending joy will be their visible honor and adornment.

instances.english_text: While sorrow and sighing flee.
instances.explanation: Sorrow and sighing are personified as people who run away, emphasizing their complete removal from the redeemed.

deliberation: Identified the comparison of humans to grass—a conventional biblical simile stressing mortality. Other elements are straightforward.

instances.english_text: Mortals who fare like grass
ground: frailty, brevity of life, susceptibility to withering
instances.explanation: Humans are explicitly compared to grass, highlighting their transience and unworthiness of fear.

deliberation: ‘Stretching out the heavens’ and ‘founding the earth’ use building/tenting imagery for creation, a standard metaphor in Isaiah. The dread of the oppressor is literal fear; ‘where is the wrath’ is rhetorical, not figurative in itself.

instances.english_text: Who stretched out the skies and made firm the earth!
ground: effort of laying out and fixing a dwelling
instances.explanation: Creating heavens and earth is pictured as stretching out a tent and laying a foundation, using construction/tent imagery for God’s cosmic work.

deliberation: The verse promises the quick release of the one who crouches/bends (a prisoner). The imagery may be vivid but can be read as literal description of a captive’s posture and liberation from a literal ‘pit’ and hunger. No clearly marked figurative expression distinct from the straightforward sense.

‘Stirs up the sea so that its waves roar’ uses storm imagery. While God’s control of the literal sea is likely in view, in Isaiah this often also evokes His mastery over chaos; still, the language itself is metaphorical: God as one who agitates a great body of water like a person.

instances.english_text: Who stirs up the sea into roaring waves
target: His ability to control creation and nations
vehicle: a person agitating the sea and its waves
ground: command over great, potentially chaotic forces
capacity to arouse or still tumult
instances.explanation: God is depicted as the one who causes the sea and its waves to roar, evoking a metaphor of His active mastery over chaotic forces.

deliberation: Found three distinct metaphors: (1) God ‘putting’ His words in someone’s mouth; (2) covering them ‘in the shadow of my hand’; and (3) ‘planting the heavens’ and ‘founding the earth’—creation as planting/building. All are standard but clearly figurative.

instances.english_text: I have put My words in your mouth
vehicle: placing an object into a mouth
ground: God directly supplies what is spoken
instances.explanation: God’s giving of a message is portrayed as physically placing words into the prophet’s mouth, emphasizing direct inspiration.

instances.english_text: And sheltered you with My hand
vehicle: shadow of a hand providing cover
ground: being encompassed by a stronger party
instances.explanation: Protection is depicted as being hidden under the shadow of God’s hand, a bodily metaphor for close, encompassing care.

instances.english_text: I, who planted the skies and made firm the earth
instances.explanation: God’s creation of heavens and earth is portrayed as planting and laying foundations, borrowing images from gardening and building.

deliberation: Two intertwined figures: Jerusalem personified as a woman told to wake up and rise, and the ‘cup of wrath’/‘bowl of reeling’—a metaphor for experiencing divine judgment like intoxication.

instances.english_text: Rouse, rouse yourself! Arise, O Jerusalem,
vehicle: a sleeping woman who can awaken and stand up
ground: capacity to change state from passivity to alertness
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is addressed as a person who can wake up and stand, personifying the city and its people as a woman needing to rouse herself.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר שָׁתִית מִיַּד יְהוָה אֶת־כּוֹס חֲמָתוֹ ... כּוֹס הַתַּרְעֵלָה שָׁתִית מָצִית
instances.english_text: You who from the LORD’s hand have drunk His wrath-filled cup, ... the bowl, the cup of reeling you have drained to the dregs.
vehicle: cup/bowl of intoxicating drink causing reeling
ground: overwhelming, disorienting effect imposed by another
having to accept a measured portion of fate
posture: prophetic indictment and transition to comfort
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is pictured as a cup of intoxicating drink that Jerusalem has drunk to the last drop, causing her staggering—an extended metaphor for severe judgment.

deliberation: Jerusalem (fem. ‘she’) is depicted as a mother with children who should guide or hold her hand, but none do. This continues the city-as-woman personification.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵין־מְנַהֵל לָהּ מִכָּל־בָּנִים יָלָדָה וְאֵין מַחֲזִיק בְּיָדָהּ מִכָּל־בָּנִים גִּדֵּלָה
instances.english_text: She has none to guide her of all the children she bore; none takes her by the hand, of all the children she reared.
vehicle: a forsaken mother with unguiding children
ground: vulnerability, abandonment, lack of support from those she raised
instances.explanation: The city is personified as a mother whose children do not lead or hold her hand, dramatizing Jerusalem’s utter abandonment.

deliberation: Continues addressing Zion as ‘you’ (fem.), with calamities ‘befalling’ her and the question ‘who can comfort you’—again city personification. The pairing ‘famine and sword’ likely functions as a merism for comprehensive disaster.

instances.english_text: These two things have befallen you ... how shall I comfort you?
vehicle: an individual woman suffering multiple blows needing comfort
ground: capacity to undergo misfortune and receive consolation
intimate relationship with God as comforter
instances.explanation: Zion is treated as a person to whom calamities ‘happen’ and who needs to be comforted, personifying the city and its disasters.

deliberation: Identified one explicit simile: sons lying at every street corner are ‘like an antelope caught in a net.’ ‘Filled with the wrath of YHWH’ continues the wrath-as-liquid/cup metaphor, but the clearest marked figure here is the simile.

instances.english_text: Like an antelope caught in a net
target: Jerusalem’s sons lying in the streets
vehicle: an antelope caught in a net
instances.explanation: The fainting sons are compared to a trapped antelope, highlighting their utter helplessness under divine judgment and foreign power.

deliberation: Jerusalem is addressed as ‘afflicted’ and ‘drunk, but not with wine.’ This is a metaphor of spiritual/social stupor due to God’s wrath rather than literal intoxication.

instances.english_text: Unhappy one, who are drunk, but not with wine!
ground: disorientation, loss of control, staggering under an influence
overwhelming effect of what has been ‘taken in’
instances.explanation: The city is personified as a woman drunk—not from wine but from God’s dealings—portraying her judgment-induced stupor as intoxication.

deliberation: The ‘cup of reeling’ and ‘cup of my wrath’ in her hand that she will not drink again continues the extended cup-of-wrath metaphor, now with removal of the cup as the end of judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: לָקַחְתִּי מִיָּדֵךְ אֶת־כּוֹס הַתַּרְעֵלָה אֶת־קֻבַּעַת כּוֹס חֲמָתִי לֹא־תוֹסִיפִי לִשְׁתּוֹתָהּ עוֹד
instances.english_text: Herewith I take from your hand the cup of reeling, the bowl, the cup of My wrath; you shall never drink it again.
vehicle: cup/bowl of intoxicating drink causing staggering
ground: judgment as something handed over and consumed, producing staggering and distress
having to accept one’s allotted fate
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is again represented as a cup that Jerusalem has had to drink; taking the cup away symbolizes the end of her judgment.

deliberation: Main image is the oppressors walking over the bowed victim, and Jerusalem’s back made ‘like the ground’ and ‘like a street’—a strong simile/hyperbole for humiliation. I focus on that explicit ‘like’ imagery.

instances.english_text: So that you made your back like the ground, like a street for passersby.
vehicle: ground and a street trampled by passersby
ground: being walked over and treated as nothing
posture: prophetic protest and promise of reversal
instances.explanation: Jerusalem’s back is compared to ground and a street trampled by others, a hyperbolic simile portraying utter humiliation under her tormentors.
